title: 108_hr779
content: The Act titled "Wartime Parity and Justice Act of 2003" allows certain individuals to be eligible under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988. Eligibility criteria for individuals under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 include being of Japanese ancestry, forcibly brought to the US from Central or South America during a specific period, living on August 10, 1988, meeting certain requirements, and not having received prior payment under the Act. Eligibility criteria for individuals under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 include being of Japanese ancestry, forcibly brought to the US from Central or South America during a specific period, living on August 10, 1988, meeting certain requirements, and not having received prior payment under the Act. Additionally, eligibility extends to individuals born to eligible individuals during a specific period and location, who were living on August 10, 1988. The eligibility criteria for individuals under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 include being of Japanese ancestry, living on August 10, 1988, and meeting specific requirements during the evacuation, relocation, or internment period. This includes individuals who were citizens or permanent residents, had their employment terminated due to their Japanese ancestry, were dependent children of eligible individuals, and not having received prior payment under the Act. Individuals eligible under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 must meet specific requirements during the evacuation, relocation, or internment period and be of Japanese ancestry. They should have been legally in the United States during that time but made ineligible for citizenship or permanent residence due to their Japanese ancestry. Prisoner exchanges with Japan during the period of December 7, 1941, to September 2, 1945, do not preclude eligibility. The United States apologizes for violating the civil liberties and constitutional rights of individuals of Japanese ancestry during the evacuation, relocation, or internment period. The President is required to send a personal letter of apology to each affected individual. The Civil Liberties Act of 1988 applies to eligible individuals, with the Attorney General responsible for identifying and locating them within 12 months. Eligible individuals can notify the Attorney General of their status. The Attorney General must determine the eligibility of individuals under section 2 within 1 year of locating them or receiving notification. Eligible individuals can seek judicial review of compensation denial within 6 years. Payments from court cases are allowed under certain circumstances. Individuals eligible under specific sections of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 may receive payment under certain conditions, even if they have previously accepted payment from a court case related to acts described in the Act. However, any payment received under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988 will be reduced by the amount previously received from a court judgment or settlement. SEC. 5. CORRECTION OF IMMIGRATION STATUS. Individuals described in section 2(a) will not be considered unlawfully present in the US during evacuation, relocation, or internment. Government agencies must correct any records indicating unlawful presence during that period. SEC. 6. FULL DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION. SEC. 6. FULL DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION. The US government must disclose all information related to the forcible removal and internment of individuals from Central and South America during the evacuation period. The President is also required to share this information with other countries. SEC. 7. TRUST FUND. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund will be invested according to specified regulations and used for payments to eligible individuals and by the Board of Directors. Appropriations are authorized as necessary for Fund operations. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Appropriations of $45,000,000 are authorized for disbursements by the Board of Directors under section 8. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund is reestablished and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. $45,000,000 in appropriations are authorized for disbursements by the Board of Directors under section 8. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund Board of Directors is established to make disbursements for research and public education activities related to the evacuation, relocation, and internment of individuals of Japanese ancestry. Funds can also be used for administrative expenses of the Board. Membership and staff details are outlined in the Civil Liberties Act. The Civil Liberties Public Education Fund Board of Directors is subject to the same provisions as the Board established under section 106 of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. The terms ``evacuation, relocation, or internment period'' and ``permanent resident alien'' are defined in section 108 of the Civil Liberties Act of 1988.
